qas.question: Who became the Democratic nominee, half way through 2003?
Dean's admiration for internet campaigning accredited his strength as what?
What did Dean's backers become known as?
What government position has Howard Dean previously held?
Which of Bush's policies did Dean criticize most notably?

plausible_answers.text: the apparent front runner for the Democratic nomination

qas.question: What status had Senator Lieberman gained in 2003?
How well did Senator Lieberman perform in the polls in 2003?
What did Senator Lieberman have that helped him further his campaign?
What method did Senator Lieberman use that helped him successfully raise funds?
Where did most of Senator Lieberman's donations come from?

context: By summer of 2003, <a0_0>Howard Dean<a0_0/> had become <b5_0>the apparent front runner for the Democratic nomination<b5_0/>, performing <b6_0>strongly<b6_0/> in most polls and leading the pack with <b7_0>the largest campaign war chest<b7_0/>. Dean's strength as <a1_0>a fund raiser<a1_0/> was attributed mainly to his embrace of <b8_0>the Internet<b8_0/> for campaigning. The majority of his donations came from <b9_0>individual supporters<b9_0/>, who became known as Deanites, or, more commonly, <a2_0>Deaniacs<a2_0/>. Generally regarded as a pragmatic centrist during his time as <a3_0>governor<a3_0/>, Dean emerged during his presidential campaign as a left-wing populist, denouncing the policies of the Bush administration (especially <a4_0>the 2003 invasion of Iraq<a4_0/>) as well as fellow Democrats, who, in his view, failed to strongly oppose them. Senator Lieberman, a liberal on domestic issues but a hawk on the War on Terror, failed to gain traction with liberal Democratic primary voters.
